title: 106_s2712
content: The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" is the short title of this Act. The purpose of the Act is outlined in Section 2, which includes findings and purposes. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" aims to consolidate financial and performance management reports to eliminate duplication of effort and provide more useful information to Congress. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" aims to provide more meaningful financial and performance management information to Congress, the President, and the public, improve the quality of agency information, and enhance coordination and efficiency in reporting. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" amends Chapter 35 of title 31, United States Code by adding a section on reports consolidation. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports with the approval of the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. These reports can be consolidated into an annual report to be submitted to the President, the Director of the Office of Management and Budget, and Congress within 150 days after the end of the agency's fiscal year. This consolidation includes various agency-specific reports outlined in the Act. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports with approval from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. This includes agency-specific reports like the biennial financial management improvement plan by the Secretary of Defense and the annual report of the Attorney General. Other statutorily required reports can be included if the agency head determines it will enhance the usefulness of the information to decision makers and consults with relevant congressional committees. The "Reports Consolidation Act of 2000" allows executive agencies to adjust the frequency and due dates of statutorily required reports with approval from the Director of the Office of Management and Budget. A report under subsection (a) may be referred to as a performance and accountability report if it incorporates the agency's program performance report under section 1116. If it does not incorporate the program performance report, it should include a summary of the most significant portions of the report. Additionally, the report should include a statement from the agency's inspector general summarizing the most serious management and performance challenges facing the agency. The agency head must provide a statement to the inspector general at least 30 days before the report's due date. The agency head can comment on the inspector general's statement but cannot modify it. The report must include a transmittal letter from the agency head assessing the completeness and reliability of performance and financial data used in the report. Any inadequacies in the data must be described, along with actions being taken to resolve them. The agency must submit a consolidated report within 180 days after the end of its fiscal year for fiscal years 2000 and 2001. Amendments are made to sections related to audited financial statements, including changes to reporting requirements and the elimination of certain subsections. SEC. 5. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO PROGRAM PERFORMANCE REPORTS. This section amends the report due date for agencies under Section 1116(a) of title 31, United States Code, allowing for submission within 150 days after the end of the fiscal year, with a special rule for fiscal years 2000 and 2001 permitting submission within 180 days. Section 1116(e) of title 31, United States Code, is amended to require program performance reports to include an assessment by the agency head on the completeness and reliability of performance data, along with actions taken to address any inadequacies. If the report is part of a submission under section 3516, the requirements of section 3516(e) apply instead.
